charts.description: These data represent the quantities of research products divided by category. The Text Collection and Linked Open Data categories both have 4 items, making them the most represented categories. The Digital Scholarly Edition and Ontology categories follow, each containing 3 products and reflecting similar levels of output in these areas. Finally, the Software category has 2 products, representing a lower output compared to the others. These quantities offer an overview of the most active areas and those with lower production, highlighting differences in research activity across categories.

charts.description:
Which are the most influencial organizations?
A number of organizations from all over the world have been involved in projects related to Italian Digital Cultural Heritage. Some of them have been taking part in several endeavours, especially thanks to the contributions of their domain's Research Centres and Working Groups.
charts.query:
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
SELECT ?label (COUNT(DISTINCT ?researchProduct) AS ?count) 
WHERE { 
 ?researchProduct a <https://schema.org/Dataset> . 
 ?researchProduct ?contributor ?organization . 
 GRAPH ?g { ?organization a <https://schema.org/Organization> .
 ?organization rdfs:label ?organizationLabel . 
 BIND(STR(?organizationLabel) AS ?label) 
}} 
GROUP BY ?label 
ORDER BY DESC(?count) 
LIMIT 6

PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
SELECT ?geonames ?label (COUNT(DISTINCT ?geonames) AS ?count) 
WHERE { ?organization a <https://schema.org/Organization> .
?organization <https://schema.org/location> ?geonames. 
?geonames rdfs:label ?label} 
GROUP BY ?geonames ?label 
ORDER BY ?geonames
charts.title: International scholarly research on Italian Digital Cultural Heritage
charts.description: This map illustrates the geographical spread of cities actively participating in various projects, offering a clear visualization of the global reach and concentrated regional involvement in these research activities. By showcasing each location, it emphasizes both the widespread nature and the specific clustering of initiatives around the world. Each city marks a point of engagement, revealing the diversity of regions committed to advancing the project’s objectives. The map’s visual distribution not only highlights the project's global influence but also provides insights into areas with high activity, making it easier to identify regional trends and collaborative hubs.

Understanding how research happens in the Digital Humanities starts with documenting methodologies. TaDiRAH (Taxonomy of Digital Research Activities in the Humanities) helps classify these methods, making research more transparent and reproducible. This chart maps the most used TaDiRAH terms, revealing the distribution of key methodologies and shedding light on dominant and emerging research practices.
charts.title: Research patterns and Methodologies

charts.description: Digital Humanities research is a growing field, with many projects still in development. This graph shows the status of documented research products, revealing that works-in-progress outnumber completed ones. This trend highlights the field’s continuous evolution, where new methodologies, tools, and discoveries drive ongoing innovation and expansion.
